audio_caption: The clip begins with an urgent male voice warning "now we're going to pay for it". He cites scientists who are allegedly saying "we're heading into a new ice age". He proceeds to reference a Time Magazine article from "Monday, June 24th, 1974". This shifts into a measured, documentary-like male voice that says, "Yes, to quote the title of Penn and Teller's TV series, this video and the next will look at bullshit, or to put it more politely, urban myths, that have grown up around the subject of climate change". The tone is informative.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing climate change and amateur research, contrasting it with expert research from previous videos. The speaker's tone is informative and conversational. He mentions Penn and Teller's "bullshit" and notes similar claims in internet blogs and mainstream media. He goes on to cite claims in Time Magazine in 1975, Senator James Inhoff, George Will citing the New York Times, and Michael Crichtonâ€™s book "State of Fear."

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing 1970s climate science, stating that "all the climate scientists believed an ice age was coming." He dismisses popular news sources as unreliable compared to scientific journals. Another male voice then objects, citing "Time magazine." The first speaker counters that Time is not peer-reviewed and prone to misreporting, urging the listener to "read the story" and identify the source of the ice age claim.

The audio clip consists primarily of a male speaker discussing a story about scientists who believed the earth was cooling, but one of whom did not believe an ice age was coming. He questions why the magazine that published the story had to resort to unnamed sources to get its information. The speaker has a measured and slightly critical tone. Intermittently, there's the sound of static crackling faintly in the background.

A male speaker poses a question about "climatologists in the 1970s" and their acceptance of a "coming ice age." He then suggests that searching through "Time and Newsweek" is not the best way to find out. The speaker has a neutral and informative tone.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker. Speaking in a factual tone, he introduces the need to look at scientific literature, noting an admission of "great uncertainty about the climate in the 1970s." He then questions if there was any consensus, mentioning predictions of "another ice age." The speaker continues by suggesting that if most scientists predicted an ice age, there should be scientific papers to support it, drawing a contrast to the abundance of papers supporting "anthropogenic climate change."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker delivering factual information in a neutral tone, referencing a study from the "Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society" that analyzed scientific literature. The speaker elaborates on the study, indicating that three climatologists found seven papers predicting global cooling but a greater number of articles predicting global warming. The speaker continues, giving reasons for the climate predictions and that climatologists suspected, and we now know, that the cooling was caused by pollution.

A male speaker discusses climate change, mentioning that "global warming caused by carbon dioxide" would eventually "overwhelm any global cooling caused by pollution." He then questions why the media reported scientists predicting "global cooling." This is followed by a sound of something slamming.

The audio clip begins with a conversational exchange between what appears to be one speaker followed by another, seemingly disagreeing with a prior assertion about the simplicity of the news in the 1970s. The second speaker mentions, "they weren't," followed by additional statements. The same male speaker continues to speak with a slight tone of disappointment.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker inquiring "How do I know?" before referencing a "1975 New York Times story." The speaker then describes a George Will column from the previous year, stating that it "reported many signs that Earth may be heading for another Ice Age." The speaker speaks in an informative tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker recounting a story about tracking down an article, "Warming Trends Seen in Climate", and being surprised that it contradicted a claim made by George Will about an impending ice age. He mentions finding not one but three columns in which Will made the claim, specifically mentioning 1992, 2004, and last year. The speaker has a slightly conversational and anecdotal tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Senator Inhofe's use of a quote, highlighting that it originated from a scientific body, rather than the popular media. The speaker proceeds to share Inhofe's quote from a 1974 report by the National Science Board: "Judging from the record of the past interglacial ages, the present time of high temperatures should be drawing to an end, leading into the next glacial age." The speaker then notes that Inhofe omitted the phrase "20,000 years from now" from the original report, which is similar to the 16,000-year estimate for the next ice age. The speaker's tone is informative and analytical.

A male speaker is discussing an urban myth and its propagation, stating "for the purposes of propagating an urban myth." His tone is analytical and measured. He refers to a claim about "a consensus on an imminent ice age" as something that "does the rounds unchecked," even when disguised as science.

The audio clip begins with an introduction to Headline Earth, promising to explain global warming. A female speaker mentions a trend or scare of "global cooling" in the 1970s. A male speaker takes over, asserting there was no scientific consensus about the climate in the 1960s, only a realization that the climate was changing. He continues, criticizing that climatologists have got the "global warming thing wrong" and that they predicted global cooling in the 1970s. The male speaker then asks what kind of individual would want to manufacture misleading information to discredit them.
